title: How to Make a Pitcher of Bloody Marys

parts.name: Making the Bloody Mary Base Mix

steps.headline: Grate the horseradish.
steps.description: Use a small cheese grater or microplane grater to mince the fresh horseradish. Transfer the grated horseradish to a mortar, a small metal bowl, or a heavy-duty glass or ceramic bowl. You can also use 1 tablespoon (15 g) of prepared horseradish instead, or omit the horseradish entirely if you want a milder Bloody Mary.

steps.headline: Muddle the horseradish and spices.
steps.description: Add the celery seed, black pepper, and salt to the bowl with the grated horseradish. Use a pestle or wooden spoon to pulverize the spices and muddle the mixture together into a paste. If you omitted the horseradish, grind the remaining spices together.

steps.headline: Combine all the juices, spices, and seasonings for the base.
steps.description: Transfer the horseradish mixture to a large pitcher that can hold at least 2 quarts (1.9 L) of liquid. Pour in 6 cups (1.4 L) of tomato juice, 1 cup (235 ml) of dill pickle juice, and ½ cup (118 ml) of lemon juice, and stir the mixture to incorporate the spices. Finally, add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of Worcestershire sauce and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of hot sauce, then stir to combine. Tabasco is a favorite for Bloody Marys, but you can use any hot sauce you like.

steps.headline: Chill the base for at least 1 hour.
steps.description: Once you’ve stirred in all the ingredients, transfer the pitcher to the refrigerator and let it chill and marinate. The longer you leave the base to chill, the more the flavors will marry and the better the Bloody Marys will taste. If you have the time, leave the base to marinate overnight. Cover the pitcher with a lid or plastic wrap if you're going to be marinating it for longer than an hour. This Bloody Mary base will last in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.

steps.headline: Fill 8 highball glasses halfway with ice.
steps.description: Bloody Marys are typically served chilled and on ice. If your party has fewer people, only fill as many glasses as you need. To accommodate more people, you can either make a double batch or serve the Bloody Marys in smaller cocktail glasses.

steps.headline: Pour 2 ounces (59 ml) of vodka into each glass.
steps.description: Use a 1-ounce (30-ml) shot glass to measure the alcohol. You can adjust the alcohol ratio for individual preferences. To make a virgin Bloody Mary, add ice and the base mixture to the glass, but omit the alcohol completely. You can combine the vodka and Bloody Mary mix together in the pitcher for convenience, but this doesn’t allow you to adjust the alcohol content for each cocktail.

steps.headline: Pour the Bloody Mary base into the glass.
steps.description: Stir the pitcher and then fill each glass the rest of the way with the chilled Bloody Mary base. Stir each cocktail with a small spoon to combine the alcohol and base. If you have any Bloody Mary base leftover, cover it and place it back in the refrigerator. If you opted to combine the alcohol and base in the pitcher, stir the pitcher of liquid before each pour to prevent the 2 from separating.

steps.headline: Garnish each glass with a lemon wedge and celery stalk.
steps.description: Before serving, add a celery stalk to each glass,and place a lemon wedge on the rim. You can also garnish the glass with fresh parsley or cilantro, pickles, olives, cucumber spears, or other toppings. To cut the lemon into wedges, cut off the top and bottom of the lemon. Slice the lemon in half lengthwise, and then cut the halves in half again. Finally, cut the quarters into eighths to create the wedges. To serve the drink with pickles or olives, skewer the garnish on a toothpick to keep it from falling into the drink.

steps.headline: Use white tequila in place of vodka to make a Bloody Maria.
steps.description: Many people prefer to use tequila instead of vodka in their Bloody Marys, to the point where this variation even has its own name: a Blood Maria. To make this variation, make the Bloody Mary base as usual, but mix the base with the same amount of white tequila in place of the vodka.

steps.headline: Try a spicy and smoky mezcal Mary.
steps.description: Mezcal is a type of spirit that’s similar to tequila in the way it’s produced, but it has a distinctive and smoky flavor that tequila lacks. To make a smoky and rich Bloody Mary, replace the vodka with equal parts mezcal and mix it with the Bloody Mary base.

steps.headline: Make a creamy tomato Bloody Mary.
steps.description: Everybody loves a creamy tomato soup, and you can recreate this by making a creamy tomato Bloody Mary. After you combine the base with the vodka, add a dollop of crème fraîche to each Bloody Mary and stir to combine. Crème fraîche is similar to sour cream, but it’s richer, thicker, and less tangy.

steps.headline: Replace the tomato juice with clamato to make Caesars.
steps.description: The Caesar is a cocktail similar to the Bloody Mary, but the major difference is that you use clamato juice (tomato juice mixed with clam broth). When making the Bloody Mary base, replace the tomato juice with the same amount of clamato juice to make a pitcher of Caesars instead. You can also make a Caesar with gin or tequila instead of vodka.
